inlineContent.text: object when the user asks for a visual code to use with a scanner. A visual code is a bar code or QR code that embeds information about a transaction. For example, an app might provide a visual code to facilitate payment for services. Apps can also use visual codes to communicate a user’s contact information.
To handle this intent, the handler object in your Intents extension must adopt the
protocol. Your handler should confirm the request and create an
object with an image containing the visual code. Siri handles the display of the provided visual code in order to scan it.
The following table lists additional attributes of this intent object:

When performing a search, Siri automatically asks the user to unlock a currently locked device. You don’t need to explicitly ask to unlock the device. In addition, Siri always prompts the user to confirm the request before asking your Intents extension to handle it.

Users can ask Siri to display visual codes in a variety of ways. The table below provides a few sample phrases in different languages. You can use these phrases during testing to trigger your intents. This list isn’t exhaustive and Siri may recognize many other phrases.
顯示我的通訊錄二維碼
תראי את הקוד QR הפרטי שלי
Mostrami il mio codice QR personale
Mostra il mio codice di pagamento
自分の支払いコードを表示
Mostra meu código QR de pagamento
โชว์คิวอาร์โค้ดของฉัน
แสดงโค้ดการจ่ายเงินของฉัน

abstract.text: Empower people to customize interactions for your app on their device.
A request for a visual code to use for exchanging payment and contact information.
Initializes the intent object with information about the requested type of code.
The type of visual code requested by the user.
The handler interface for displaying your app’s visual codes.
Your app’s response to a request for a visual code.
A request to fulfill in your app or Intents extension.
Constants indicating the purpose of the visual code.
A protocol that enables an object to be encoded and decoded for archiving and distribution.
A protocol that objects adopt to provide functional copies of themselves.
The group of methods that are fundamental to all Objective-C objects.
A protocol that enables encoding and decoding in a manner that is robust against object substitution attacks.
A type that can be hashed into a `Hasher` to produce an integer hash value.
A type that can be compared for value equality.
A type with a customized textual representation.
A type with a customized textual representation suitable for debugging purposes.
A type whose instances can be encoded, and appropriately passed, as elements of a C `va_list`.
